title: How to Dress and Look Fashionable when You Still Wear Kid's Sizes

steps.headline: Make the most of the clothes you already have.
steps.description: Before you even think about buying any new clothes, look through your wardrobe or closet. Don't dismiss things just because they are labeled an age size you no longer are. Try everything on, if it still fits and you just don't wear it that often, you may be able to style if differently. If you feel something is childish or that you're now too grown up for it, donate it to charity or, consider repurposing.

steps.headline: Know your body shape.
steps.description:
Kids clothes don't account for busts, hips and broad shoulders. You might have a larger waist size than a kid your height. Whatever your age, you may be longer in the body or legs than a typical child your size or height. Know your measurements and what looks good on you. Children's clothes are often labeled for heights, e.g., "for up to 140cm". If you know how tall you are and your other measurements, you can save time not even trying on things that aren't going to fit. If adult miniskirts and short-shorts, swamp you, these are the types of clothing you can look for in children's sizes. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9f\/Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9f\/Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Don't restrict your choices to clothes marketed towards girls or boys.
steps.description: A petite, slim young woman can look fashionable in pants or trousers aimed at young boys. If you don't want to look girly, boys clothes may be a better option as they won't be emblazoned with childish glitter or lurid pink. Anyone looking for pastel colors shouldn't over look clothing aimed at girls. Boys clothing is typically primary colors. If you're a slim guy who looks great in lemo-yellow, don't be put off buying a plain tee shirt in this color from the girls section - cut the label out if it bothers you. Unisex children's wear is an option for anyone it fits, look for wardrobe staples such as tee shirts, shorts, pants/trousers and sweatshirts in larger department stores and mainstream shops. There a very high chance than these items are virtually identical to adult versions and their likely made on the same production lines so if they are a better fit on you, why not wear them? It's how you style them that counts .

steps.headline: Look into for getting items fitted or tailored.
steps.description: A good tailor or seamstress can adjust clothing to fit and flatter. Making pants/trousers, shorts and skirts shorter is relatively simple - you can attempt this yourself if you're handy with a needle/sewing machine. Adjusting a jacket or fitted dress is more complex and you may want an expert to do this for you.

steps.headline: If you're looking for formal wear, try clothes intended for children to wear at weddings.
steps.description: Many retailers sell suits for children, which styled correctly, can look great on anyone they fit well. If you can purchase the jacket and trousers separately, you may get a better fit - ask the retailer. Bridesmaid dresses can be an option for proms or other formal occasion. If the fit of a child's dress is good on you and it's just the color you don't like, you could dye it. Embellishments can be added or taken way, you could even consider making it more grown up by adding a sexy slit to the skirt.

steps.headline: Choose your footwear carefully.
steps.description: If you have such small feet that you can only wear kids shoes it can be a nightmare, especially if you want a high heel or anything that doesn't do up with Velcro! Big brands such as Converse, Uggs and Timberland are options, the kids sizes are almost the same designs as the adult sizes. Shop around for dressier shoes, as said before, childish embellishments can be removed.

steps.headline: Wear age appropriate underwear.
steps.description: Your clothes will look better with the right clothes on underneath. A good bra can improve the fit or a shirt or dress. Chest binders can help form fitting tops give you the look you're after. Shaping underwear, for example Spanx, can be helpful, especially if finding dresses that fit well at the bust, waist and hips difficult.

steps.headline: Make sure your clothes work for you.
steps.description: If you're not that mobile, choose clothes that won't hamper your use of a cane, wheelchair or other device. Similarly, if you don't have to move around in your clothes or shoes, you can pick impractical things - does it matter if your skirt doesn't do up if you'll be sitting on your wheelchair all day and the fastening is at the back - if you're comfortable and it looks good, go for it.

steps.headline: If you don't want to look like a kid wearing their parents clothes, use accessories to make your outfits age appropriate.
steps.description: Many accessories are one size fits all and good for all ages. Belts, belt buckles, hats, scarves, bags/purses, sunglasses, jewelry etc can all help make you look the age you want to.

steps.headline: If you want to avoid looking like "mutton dressed as lamb", first of all, think hard about if it's you, or others, that will be "bothered" by your clothes.
steps.description: As long as you're not breaching health and safety regulations, you can wear whatever you want, but, you may feel more comfortable avoiding garments with popular kids characters on, no matter how well they fit. Lace, sparkles, glitter, bows, ribbons are a matter of personal choice, wear them if you want, but, some people may perceive you as childish.

text:
Make the most of the clothes you already have. Before you even think about buying any new clothes, look through your wardrobe or closet. Don't dismiss things just because they are labeled an age size you no longer are. Try everything on, if it still fits and you just don't wear it that often, you may be able to style if differently. If you feel something is childish or that you're now too grown up for it, donate it to charity or, consider repurposing. Know your body shape. Kids clothes don't account for busts, hips and broad shoulders. You might have a larger waist size than a kid your height. Whatever your age, you may be longer in the body or legs than a typical child your size or height. Know your measurements and what looks good on you. Children's clothes are often labeled for heights, e.g., "for up to 140cm". If you know how tall you are and your other measurements, you can save time not even trying on things that aren't going to fit. If adult miniskirts and short-shorts, swamp you, these are the types of clothing you can look for in children's sizes. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9f\/Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9f\/Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Dress-and-Look-Fashionable-when-You-Still-Wear-Kid%27s-Sizes-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Don't restrict your choices to clothes marketed towards girls or boys. A petite, slim young woman can look fashionable in pants or trousers aimed at young boys. If you don't want to look girly, boys clothes may be a better option as they won't be emblazoned with childish glitter or lurid pink. Anyone looking for pastel colors shouldn't over look clothing aimed at girls. Boys clothing is typically primary colors. If you're a slim guy who looks great in lemo-yellow, don't be put off buying a plain tee shirt in this color from the girls section - cut the label out if it bothers you. Unisex children's wear is an option for anyone it fits, look for wardrobe staples such as tee shirts, shorts, pants/trousers and sweatshirts in larger department stores and mainstream shops. There a very high chance than these items are virtually identical to adult versions and their likely made on the same production lines so if they are a better fit on you, why not wear them? It's how you style them that counts . Look into for getting items fitted or tailored. A good tailor or seamstress can adjust clothing to fit and flatter. Making pants/trousers, shorts and skirts shorter is relatively simple - you can attempt this yourself if you're handy with a needle/sewing machine. Adjusting a jacket or fitted dress is more complex and you may want an expert to do this for you. If you're looking for formal wear, try clothes intended for children to wear at weddings. Many retailers sell suits for children, which styled correctly, can look great on anyone they fit well. If you can purchase the jacket and trousers separately, you may get a better fit - ask the retailer. Bridesmaid dresses can be an option for proms or other formal occasion. If the fit of a child's dress is good on you and it's just the color you don't like, you could dye it. Embellishments can be added or taken way, you could even consider making it more grown up by adding a sexy slit to the skirt. Choose your footwear carefully. If you have such small feet that you can only wear kids shoes it can be a nightmare, especially if you want a high heel or anything that doesn't do up with Velcro! Big brands such as Converse, Uggs and Timberland are options, the kids sizes are almost the same designs as the adult sizes. Shop around for dressier shoes, as said before, childish embellishments can be removed. Wear age appropriate underwear. Your clothes will look better with the right clothes on underneath. A good bra can improve the fit or a shirt or dress. Chest binders can help form fitting tops give you the look you're after. Shaping underwear, for example Spanx, can be helpful, especially if finding dresses that fit well at the bust, waist and hips difficult. Make sure your clothes work for you. If you're not that mobile, choose clothes that won't hamper your use of a cane, wheelchair or other device. Similarly, if you don't have to move around in your clothes or shoes, you can pick impractical things - does it matter if your skirt doesn't do up if you'll be sitting on your wheelchair all day and the fastening is at the back - if you're comfortable and it looks good, go for it. If you don't want to look like a kid wearing their parents clothes, use accessories to make your outfits age appropriate. Many accessories are one size fits all and good for all ages. Belts, belt buckles, hats, scarves, bags/purses, sunglasses, jewelry etc can all help make you look the age you want to. If you want to avoid looking like "mutton dressed as lamb", first of all, think hard about if it's you, or others, that will be "bothered" by your clothes. As long as you're not breaching health and safety regulations, you can wear whatever you want, but, you may feel more comfortable avoiding garments with popular kids characters on, no matter how well they fit. Lace, sparkles, glitter, bows, ribbons are a matter of personal choice, wear them if you want, but, some people may perceive you as childish.
